translated: “Having enjoyed the unsurpassed pleasures of love,
and having been a master in the past, O One-King,
you are now cast into a bad hell,
and you do not give up your former beauty and strength.”

original: “Pubbeva khantī ca tapo ca mayhaṁ,🔽Sampatthitā dubbhisena ahosi;
analyzed: pubbā iva khantī ca tapo ca mayha  sampatthitā dubbhisena ahosi
translated: “My patience and my austerity 🔽were fulfilled in the past, O King, but I was not successful.

original: Taṁ dāni laddhāna kathaṁ nu rāja,
analyzed: tam dāni laddhāna katham nu rāja
translated: Now that I have attained them, how can I, O King,
give up my former beauty and strength?
All things are fulfilled in this way,

original: Yasassinaṁ paññavantaṁ visayha;🔽Yaso ca laddhā purimaṁ uḷāraṁ,
analyzed: yasassinam paññavantam  ca laddhā purimam uḷāra
translated: for the famous and wise one, O King. 🔽Having attained the former high fame,
he does not give up his former beauty and strength.
Having given up pleasure for the sake of pain, O King,
or pain for the sake of pleasure, O King,
the one who is peaceful and has attained Nibbāna,

original: Sukhe ca dukkhe ca bhavanti tulyā”ti.🔽Ekarājajātakaṁ tatiyaṁ.
analyzed: sukhe ca dukkhe ca bhavanti 🔽eka rāja jātakam
translated: is the same in pleasure and pain.” 🔽The One-King Birth-Story is the third.
